Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Effect of Near-Equatorial Islands on Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine the effect of near-equatorial islands on climate. A series of experiments, first with a simple, two-dimensional model without the effects of rotation, and then with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology General Circulation Model (MIT-GCM) will be carried out to examine the effects of islands on the distribution of rainfall, the resulting wind field, and hence on large-scale circulation. Experiments with the MIT-GCM will be carried out with simplified geometries that include barriers of negligible width to ocean circulation, but not atmospheric, circulation and with different numbers, distributions, lateral dimensions, and elevations of tropical islands in order to seek scaling relationships between these measures of island extent and the response of the atmosphere and ocean.

The goals are two-fold: First, could the growth of islands to build the Maritime Continent have altered atmospheric circulation sufficiently to change the sea-surface temperature distribution in the equatorial Pacific from one resembling a permanent El Niño-like state to its present mean weak La Niña-like state? Second, can parameterizations be derived for the effects of islands on tropical precipitation and ascent that allow GCMs to include the effects of islands that are too small to be resolved in such global models? The broader impacts are high: if islands do play a major role in climate, this study will yield parameterizations that will be useful for including the effects of small islands in model simulations. In addition this work will support a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The eastern equatorial Pacific ocean is anomalously cold compared to waters to the north and south. For example, the climate of the Galapagos Islands, which are nearly on the equator, is more like that of southern California than of a Caribbean island. The coldness of the water results from upwelling of very cold water from deep in the ocean; this is in turn caused by the Trade Winds blowing the warmer surface waters westward and poleward. Every few years these Trade Winds mysteriously relax, allowing warm water from the western Pacific to slosh eastward in what we call an El Nino event. This has profound effects on weather all around the world.

            Yet during the Pliocene period, about 3 million years ago, evidence from the chemical composition of the remains of marine organisms found in deep sea sediments suggest that the waters of the equatorial eastern Pacific were always quite warm during that period, as if there were a permanent El Nino. Why was this the case?  The continents were mostly near their current configurations and while the CO2 content of the atmosphere was elevated compared to its value after the end of the last ice age, it was comparable to that of today. Yet the earth's climate was substantially warmer than today’s.

            There was one aspect of the earth's geography that was quite different during the Pliocene. The land mass of the Indonesian islands was only about 60% of today's land mass. We think that this could be important, and our work supported by this NSF grant explored the hypothesis that this missing land might account for the warmth of the eastern equatorial Pacific.

            Over tropical land, there is a strong daily cycle of showers and thunderstorms.  They tend to develop in the afternoon and reach their peak just before sunset, dying away each evening. But over the ocean, there is little daily variation in thunderstorm activity. We discovered that, averaged over a day, the air over land is warmer than over the ocean because of this daily cycle of showers and thunderstorms. This warmth leads to rising air over land and sinking air over the ocean. In today's climate, rising air over Indonesia forces air to flow westward along the equator, giving rise to the Trade Winds across the equatorial Pacific. If there was substantially less land 3 million years ago, perhaps these Trades were weaker, allowing warm water to push eastward and accounting for the warmth of the eastern Pacific during that time, and perhaps, indirectly, to the warmth of the whole climate system back then.

            Thus our research may provide a clue to an important and hitherto unappreciated aspect of the climate system, having to do with the distribution of land along the equator. This will help further our understanding of the earth's climate in general.
